block.p: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could be considered something of a C.E.O. His company? Kremlin Inc., overseer of a vast network of oil and banking concerns. As more of Russia's economy falls under state control, meetings in the Kremlin are becoming an important part of any deal maker's playbook; many analysts say the big deals cannot get done without such gatherings.

So it should come as no surprise that the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein, has written a letter to Mr. Putin asking for a meeting. The Kremlin's Web site announced the request last week. It was a Goldman analyst who first formulated the idea that the fast-growing so-called B.R.I.C. economies -- Brazil, Russia, India and China -- would inevitably outpace today's largest economies.

As more of Russia's economy falls under state control, meetings in the Kremlin are becoming an important part of any deal maker's playbook; many analysts say the big deals cannot get done without such gatherings.

So it should come as no surprise that the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein, has written a letter to Mr. Putin asking for a meeting. The Kremlin's Web site announced the request last week. It was a Goldman analyst who first formulated the idea that the fast-growing so-called B.R.I.C. economies -- Brazil, Russia, India and China -- would inevitably outpace today's largest economies.
That implies plenty of investment banking opportunities. Just last month, Goldman joined a consortium of banks that agreed to lend $22 billion to Rosneft, the state oil company.

Meeting with executives gives Mr. Putin an opportunity to display his strengths, notably a razor-sharp attention to detail, said Andrew B. Somers, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia, who has orchestrated some of the meetings.
''That leaves a positive impression of Russia'' with the executives, Mr. Somers said.
(Goldman suffered a setback on Friday when a fire in a Moscow high-rise destroyed part of its office; no one was hurt.)
